Rebecca just does not need this stress. Ross said rats had chewed through carpets, sofas, mattresses and flooring and toys have been thrown away as a precaution. The couple have been busy preparing the house and cleaning it for the new baby, but Ross said the rodents were making their lives hell and the children were scared to play.   Disgusting oozing toe that left specialist stunned at the amount of pus  In her Facebook post, Rebecca said council workers filled in holes with expanding foam, but the rats and mice just chewed straight through it. And she claimed the council said she couldn't be moved because the rodents were 'not a danger'. In her post Rebecca said: At my wits end honestly. I've kept it quite quiet until now but I've reached breaking point with baby due in a few weeks! Over the past few months we’ve had rats and mice in our house. We have contacted housing and it took them four weeks to even get someone out! They didn’t believe we had rats and mice together so they only laid poison. Rats and mice have to eat 60 per cent of their body weight to die from the poison. Obviously because there’s loads they just aren’t dying, and we all know how fast they breed! Council fill the holes with expanding foam and then they just chew back through it. All night we were up with chewing noises and came out onto the landing and they’re chewing through the ceiling! The council workers have said themselves they don’t see this ending. Pest control have just been into the attic and there’s not even any insulation in there.

title: grieving mother opens up teenage
story: NewsGrieving mother opens up about teenage son's murder in heartbreaking extracts from personal diaryKyron Webb, 15, was found gravely injured in Moston, Greater Manchester, following an unprovoked attack by two teenagersShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNeil Murphy11:57, 17 SEP 2018NewsKyron Webb, from south London, died after being stabbed in the heart "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A grieving mother who lost her teenage son to kne crime has opened up about his murder in heartbreaking extracts from her personal diary.   Kyron Webb, 15, was stabbed to death by two teenagers following an unprovoked attack in Manchester last year.  Rachel Webb, from Crystal Palace, south London, will published a book about her heartache and attempts to come to terms with her son's tragic passing The 41-year-old said: “This novel gives the mothers and families that have fallen victim to kne brutality a voice. I am a victim, I am the mother of Kyron Webb.” Below are extracts from Ms Webb's diary.   October 17, 2017 – the day Kyron was stabbed   Kyron’s dead”   This is followed by tears and screams. I can hear Kyron’s Dad crying, groaning…. I am stunned what is going on, I feel a little dazed. I am just sitting in stunned silence. More Silence.   Kyron's dead!' he says again.   I adjust myself on the sofa, 'Don't be silly! Where is my son?' “Put Kyron on the phone” I say, still in disbelief.   Then I hear more screams, I remove the handset from my ear and stare at the phone. I am trying to contemplate  this is actually real, is this actually happening? I bring the handset to my ear again and hear his dads groan: “Oh Gosh, they killed him, I hear him say, “They killed my Kyron”.   Then more cries. My brain is trying to process the words I seem to be hearing over and over again.    Kyron’s dad’s voice seems to be in a distance, its fading away. I cannot hear him anymore. In fact I cannot hear anything. I look at the television I see the lips moving but hear no sound. I think I may be going into shock.   Everything is spinning I stand up. I hear my voice. 'Where is he? What hospital is he in?' Still in disbelief I await a response. Nausea is rising.   There was no answer just screams tears wailing. I ask again irritation now forming: “What hospital is he in?” he is speaking now I take down the name, Manchester Royal infirmary. With a muttered thank you.   I hang up, frozen in shock I start to call the hospital in Manchester’  She then recounts her trip from London to Manchester's Royal Infirmary were medics were treating her son.  After what felt like forever, I arrive. They are waiting for me outside Two plain-clothes police officers, a male and female officer, stood looking at me, concern already on their faces. I felt as though I had stepped out of a patrol car into an episode of Law and Order. My body shakes as I walk towards them. They began to speak   Your son has been stabbed” the lady officer says.   How many times?” I ask,   Just the once” she replies.   “Where?” I brace myself for her response.   “The heart” she says then continues with her update.   I cannot hear them. Tears have escaped my eyes “Sorry” the female officer says, as she strokes my arm.   She realises her words are ripping my heart into a thousand pieces. I fade in and out. A doctor is in front of me, when did he arrive? Then like I had been given a shot of adrenaline, I was brought back into the moment as he says….   ‘”Kyron has been stabbed in the heart. He arrived with a faint pulse, he was found groaning, unable to speak and has lost a lot of blood.   “ Paramedics did all they could. His heart stopped upon arrival, he went into cadiac arrest. We opened him up in A&ampE, but it took us 40 minutes to get his heart started again. We rushed him to theatre, but then he had another cardiac arrest, lasting 20 minutes.    “His brain was starved of oxygen for over an hour. We are still working on him, but we fear he is brain dead and we cannot stop the bleeding. He is very critical with a one per cent chance of survival. If he does pull through, I am sorry, your son will be severely brain damaged.”   They speak to me alone to spare those in the waiting room from hearing the devastation. Again, I am screaming, I cannot breathe. I am crying, I am falling, I am becoming dizzy. I fall, it's dark.   My older sister Glenna is here, I call to her distraught all I can say is her name. I call her over and over again, it is becoming dficult to breathe, I am hyperventilating. Glenna holds onto me, no more words. We hold each other tightly and we cry.   October 18, 2017   I make my way to the side of the bed and whisper into his ears “Mummy is here now darling, sorry I took so long. Sorry I was not there to hold you. I am here now, wake up and I promise I am going to take you home. You can have whatever you want, just please wake up”.   I kiss Kyron on his forehead, it felt strange, he feels cool and clammy. There is swelling to the left side of his head which is surrounded by an aggressive bruise. “Did they hit him?” I ask the nurse. “No, that bruising is from the blood loss” she casually says as she continues to write her reports.   Kyron looks really tall, I do not remember him being so tall.   Kyron’s dad is standing on the other side of the bed. “Papa” he says, his voice shakes, he leans forward, kisses his son “Papa” he says again, and then come the tears, he sobs.   His dad is broken, weakened by his sorrow, unsure what to say “Papa” his voice is breaking. He punches the air, looks over at Kyron, looks at me then sobs uncontrollably. His anguish triggers my tears. I join him, lower my head and cry. Please wake up Kyron, I am here to take you home.

title: katie hopkins end inevitable just
story: NewsopinionKatie Hopkins' end was inevitable - she was just a story, not a journalistShe paid the price in the end, says Fleet Street FoxShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist14:40, 17 SEP 2018Newsopinion"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI have long felt sorry for Katie Hopkins.  She is a woman not only out of her depth, has not only floundered for more than a decade, but has no idea where she's gone wrong. It's hard to see her without thinking of a fly batting itself against a window until it expires, able to see the fresh air but unable to find it.  If she reads this - which she might, because she defines herself only by what others think of her - she'll assume I'm a Left-wing liberal about to rail against her Right-wing freedom of speech. No, Katie. Someone who knows more than you is going to explain how the hatred has suffocated you.  We both have epilepsy - mine very mild, hers very severe. The condition strikes in her sleep, led to her being expelled from Sandhurst, to break vertebrae and frequently dislocate her shoulders. She recently had brain surgery that ended the seizures but left her with a hole in her skull and needing to re-learn how to climb stairs.  She blames the medication she has needed since young for the fact her oldest daughter is autistic and her youngest was born with a deformed hip that required many surgeries to correct. Those would be enough disability for most people to deal with. But Katie has an extra one - a mistaken belief that she's a journalist.  Let's not be precious about the Street of Shame. It is a trade, not a profession, and the only qualication necessary is a level of enthusiasm bordering on mental illness. But somewhere along the line most journalists get training. They get it from a practical degree, a vocational course, or at worst from paying attention to people who're doing it already.  Katie became a journalist because first she became a media star, and she managed THAT with what she called being outspoken and everyone else called being a right cow.   On The Apprentice in 2006 she hogged the camera by making amusingly-nasty remarks about maternity leave, fat people, and fellow contestants. She resigned at the end of the penultimate show citing childcare concerns, which others mocked because she had known what she was getting into.  But it's perhaps worth noting both that her concerns were for two disabled daughters, and also that she was mocked mainly because she'd been so happy to mock others.   Katie sold her story for six-figure sums, had celebrity spats, and was pictured in flagrante in a field with someone else's husband. She got a regular column in her local paper the Exeter Express &amp Echo , but it ended after an online poll found 84% of the readers wanted her fired. It was a hint she did not take.   She was invited onto TV as a guarantee of ratings. Three years ago Buzzfeed reported a former staffer at This Morning said she was always willing to cause controversy from the word go.  Such programmes involve a chat with a producer in advance, and Katie would immediately come up with a firm line on something, and then wheeled on-air to spout it with little thought from either her or producers about where it would end.  So in 2013 when she told Philip and Holly she wouldn't let her children play with someone called Tyler or Chardonnay or named after geography, it was pointed out one of her children was called India and the clip went viral.   Katie learned to make money by being rude and unapologetic, and the media learned to shore up their audience figures with a wingnut. Inevitably, she was offered a national newspaper column, a place in the Big Brother house, and more opprobrium as the hate multiplied. In 2015 she used her column to denounce migrants as cockroaches, and it quietly disappeared before she popped up at another website which racked up &pound150,000 damages plus costs for her groundless claim that a pair of Muslim brothers banned from travelling to Disneyland were linked to al Qaeda. She met holocaust deniers, tweeted about being with crew of a Save the Children ship she didn't board, and had repeated applications to join UKIP rejected.  She made a habit out of getting it wrong. She moved on to LBC, left after calling for a final solution to Islamic terror, was questioned but not charged over alleged hate crimes, and more recently staged a picture with children at a school without their parents' or teachers' permission, a gross breach of journalistic ethics. She has her own website and, one hopes, has invested in some defamation legal insurance.   Now she's been sued over a defamatory tweet, lost her home, and had to enter an agreement with her creditors. All of it is due to the simple fact that she attempted to be a journalist without any of the necessary skills.   If Katie had experience of working in the media before she became its favourite monster, she'd have known that what you don't say is just as important as what you do. By all means say you're snobby about the name Charmaine, but it might be an idea to know Shakespeare was happy to use it for one of his characters.  If you make a habit of racking up legal bills for your employer, be careful with what you publish on social media. If you are caught lying, stop doing it. Steer clear of people with swastikas in their Twitter handles and  you don't know what defamation is, look it up.  But more than anything else the lesson that Katie needed to learn was this: that becoming a hate figure is a viable but short media career. She chose a path that was an ever-decreasing spiral of bile, and it was only ever going to lead her into peril. I'm not sure she knows how she got there.  She started out as entertainment, and ended up with the twin Pyrrhic victories of being praised by Donald Trump and winning an IPSO ruling against the Daily Mirror about the fact she was not detained for taking ketamine in South Africa, but for spreading racial hatred.  Now she's broke and the only people still paying attention are creditors and knicker-snfing Nazis.  Katie was not a journalist but a controversialist - built and brought down by her ignorance of how journalism works.  Her name is flung at others who make a much better fist of it, along with accusations they all want to be like her. Nothing could be further from the truth - journalists, above all things, want to be right. Katie was just a story, and it's a sad indictment of the media that it relied for attention on a sick woman spouting proto-fascist lies.   But the principle blame is on Katie herself. She had enough clues, from as early as her first interview after leaving The Apprentice when Nick Hewer said her new brand had made you famous, but it's made you loathed. And where's it going to take you now? She never seems to have asked where it would lead.  Even with training, she would never have made much of a journo. She has a thick skin and bloody-mindedness, but seems to lack empathy, accuracy, self-doubt or persuasiveness. She is a curiosity, but doesn't have any. The first rule of journalism is 'never become the story'. Not just because it's professionally embarrassing, but because all copy finishes the same way - with the word 'ends'.   * Fleet Street Fox's new book, A Bluffer's Guide To Journalism, is published in March. Pre-order here.

title: madeleine mccanns dad gerry opens
story: NewsMadeleine McCann's dad Gerry opens up about mental health struggle after daughter went missing 11 years agoGerry McCann, 50, will be speaking on air about this heartache in the hope that it will help other men struggling with their mental healthShare&nbspByHana Carter13:17, 17 SEP 2018Updated14:37, 17 SEP 2018NewsGerry McCann will be appearing on Radio 4 for a special interview "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMadeleine McCann's dad will open up about his battle with depression in the years after her disappearance as part of a special show for BBC Radio 4. Gerry McCann, 50, accepted the interview to tackle the taboo surrounding men with mental health issues. The eminent cardiologist has said that he will discuss his torment in honest, personal and sometimes painful terms for the Radio 4 show. The programme is set to feature Pearl, by Simon Armitage, a modern translation of a medieval poem about a father's grief after losing his daughter. Gerry said: As a family we'd worked with Simon Armitage before, and know what a sensitive, thoughtful writer he is.  When I read the Pearl poem, I could see echoes in it with Madeleine's situation and our loss. I decided it was a good opportunity to say something about the special bond between fathers and daughters, thinking that speaking openly might help other men in similar positions. It feels like the right time. Simon Armitage said: Pearl is one of the most moving poems in the language, written by a man grieving over the loss of his young daughter. While translating it into modern English I kept thinking of the McCann family and their daughter Madeleine.  I'd written a poem for the family to mark the one thousandth day of her disappearance, spending some time with Kate and talking to her about le without Madeleine and the campaign to find her. He added: Gerry's voice hasn't been heard as much, and after reading the poem he agreed to give an extended interview, to tell his side of the story in terms of how men deal with loss and grief in a world where they're usually expected to stay strong and silent.  The couple promised never to stop looking for their little girl, who would now be 15, after her sudden disappearance sparked a worldwide search in 2007. Kate and Gerry had ed to their apartment in Algarve's Praia da Luz after having dinner in a nearby restaurant when they found her bed empty. Their twins, Sean and Amelie, who were toddlers at the time, remained in their cots. Her whereabouts still remains a mystery despite a &pound12million police investigation. They also set up a 'Find Maddie Fund' and have raised around &pound750,000 in a bid to find her.

story: NewsMan battered three-month-old baby boy leaving him with EIGHT broken bones in arms and legsMarc Caulton, 33, left the youngster with terrible injuries after attacking him on several occasionsShare&nbspByArun Lal13:56, 17 SEP 2018Updated13:57, 17 SEP 2018NewsMarc Caulton, 33, has been jailed for four years "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who battered a three-month-old baby leaving him with eight broken bones in his arms and legs has been jailed for four years. Marc Caulton, 33, left the defenceless child with the horric injuries after attacking him on several occasions. A court heard the distressed youngster was rushed to Nottingham's Queen’s Medical Centre with a limp arm in October 2017. An x-ray confirmed his arm was badly fractured while further scans confirmed another seven breaks in both of his arms and legs.  Doctors concluded the injuries had occurred on more than one occasion and were a result of blunt force trauma, police said.  Caulton, of Stapleford, Nottinghamshire, was arrested and gave a series of excuses for the child's broken bones. These were all rejected by paediatric experts. He eventually admitted causing the injuries and pleaded guilty to grievous bodily harm, causing a child to suffer serious injury and child neglect in July this year. On Friday, he was jailed for four years, handed a letime restraining order and ordered to pay court costs at Nottingham Crown Court.  Detective Constable Chris Taylor, of Nottinghamshire Police's Child Abuse Investigation Unit, said after the case: There’s something to be said for a man who chooses to abuse a child so defenceless, a child so young they haven’t even developed the ability to ask for help. “Caulton is manipulative and has caused a cascade of devastation and confusion for the child’s family. “They now have to move on from this without any explanation as to why their son suffered such horric injuries, but I hope knowing that he is behind bars will give them some closure.

title: meet brits who believe earth
story: NewsMeet the Brits who believe the Earth is FLAT and claim 'we've been lied to in worst way'In the Flat Earth world, our planet is not set within an infinite universe but is completely aloneShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDavid HolmesCharlotte Turner12:17, 17 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/chester-flat-earther-vic-button-13258853,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDespite a wealth of scientic proof, many people still believe the Earth is flat.  The UK has seen increased interest in 'Flat Earth' groups - where members insist that our planet is shaped as a disk rather than a spherical globe.  Some even claim that we have been 'lied to in the worst way' about its shape. The Flat Earth concept goes back to ancient Greece, but the outmoded thinking has undergone a mini revival thanks to the power of the web. Groups cropping up across the country apparently agree that 'mistrust' of authority and the Internet are a factor in their growth.  They also believe the Earth is not set within an infinite universe , but is completely alone, Chester Live reports   Members of Chester Flat Earth Group, who attracted 25 people at a recent public meeting, say that it is the ability to interrogate online information provided by organisations like NASA that has presented their big opportunity to challenge the ‘lies’. Some believe Earth may be covered in a glass or plasma dome with ice walls around the edge to contain the oceans. They claim Space, the planets, the stars, rockets, the moon landings and the International Space Station  are all fake, but presented to the public as real. Theories as to how this is done include the use of computer generated images, filming in secret studios and even underwater shoots. Flat Earther Vic Button, 75, from Farndon, Cheshire, believes it’s one way in which the powerful maintain control. “It’s to make you feel as though you are unimportant, a little speck in a massive universe,” says Vic. “My aim now, for le, is to awaken people to what I see as the truth because they have been lied to, deceived on a massive scale.”  A signicant piece of evidence as far as Flat Earthers is concerned is their claim the curvature of the earth is not borne out in reality. An electrical engineer by trade, Vic said: “When you went to school – this is why I can get angry at it – there’s a ball, a globe in the classroom and they never said ‘Oh, also it could be flat or whatever’. They let it go into your head that it was like that and all the books around you. You go home and you watch Star Wars and all that and rockets going up. Now that’s all in your head. “When you research it you think rockets can’t do 25,000 mph, seven miles per second, it’s just ridiculous. They have to say that for the distances they’re saying they’d have to go. What about the fuel for it? And how can we get past the Van Allen belt, all scientists agree there’s a Van Allen belt, with fantastic temperatures. How do they get through that?” But haven’t we got pictures of the moon landings and of views of the earth taken from the moon and the International Space Station? “From the ISS, which is fake, they’ve a got a picture of the earth, which is fake, moving round but there are no images of the earth spinning round in space at all,” said Vic.  ”Lots and lots of people come to us knowing we didn’t go to the moon – that’s silly. For anybody to look at the information for five minutes would know. It’s nonsense. It’s become an absolute joke – from hammering in the plaque, the shadows are wrong. You can go on and on and on.” Vic and his fellow Flat Earther John, 49, who does not wish to give his full name, offer the following claims: ■ A photo of a moon buggy is fake because it is dust free and ‘clean as a whistle’ ■ Videos in the International Space Station are made in a secret studio ■ Footage of astronauts outside the ISS are actually made under water – with one clip accidentally revealing a man wearing a snorkel and scuba tank ■ Video shot through the ISS window appears to show a fly buzzing around in space ■ An astronaut’s hand and objects disappear in videos revealing flaws in the faked footage ■ The moon exists but isn’t a solid object ■ Our sun is not 93m miles away but much closer – and could be manmade Chester Flat Earthers believe scientists and the 500-plus people who have been to Space are part of the conspiracy. They claim these people have had to sign the Official Secrets Act and been paid to keep quiet.  Vic even alleges some astronauts have actually been killed because they ‘knew too much and were going to spill the beans’. The pair believe space disasters were faked to finesse the illusion. They claim the Space Shuttle Challenger was blown up deliberately in 1986 but with nobody on board and reckon all seven crew members are alive and well to this day. “Michael J Smith, who was allegedly on board, he now currently works for some university in America under the same name. He even looks the same,” claims John, who prefers to trust his own senses and instincts rather than what he is told. The Flat Earthers, who hold monthly meetings and street stalls in Chester city centre, get constantly ridiculed but John, who works part-time laying on activities for older people, doesn’t care. “I get laughed at. I get called an idiot. But these people are just showing they are messed up in their head, he says. Meanwhile, a Flat Earther who believes that we don't live on a globe is touring the country - to spread the truth in a secret location.

story: NewsMeghan Markle serves up meals with people affected by Grenfell Tower tragedy as she launches cookbook after secret visitsMeghan Markle came up with the idea for the Together: Our Community Cookbook after making secret trips to the communityShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor10:34, 17 SEP 2018Updated10:49, 17 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/meghan-markle-seen-cooking-new-13258748,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle can be seen cooking and serving up meals to people affected by the Grenfell Tower tragedy as she promotes a new charity cookbook. The Duchess of Sussex made several secret visits to the area before her wedding to Prince Harry, and met a group of women who came together to cook for friends, family and neighbours whose lives had been torn apart by the disaster. When she discovered they could only offer the Hubb Community Kitchen service two days a week because of funding, she suggested they released a cookbook to raise extra cash. Now the idea has become a reality, and Meghan has today released details of the book - Together: Our Community Cookbook - including a three minute video of her cooking in the kitchen with the women. She says: Together is a cookbook, but it's also the story of a west London community who gathered together in a kitchen and discovered the healing power of sharing food.  In January 2018, as I was settling into my new home in London, I met a group of women whose lives had been affected by the Grenfell fire. They had decided to get together to cook fresh food for their families and their neighbours. And so, for two days every week, these women were able to cook and share their delicious recipes together.  I'm proud to be supporting this cookbook Together. We hope you enjoy it as much as we do. The book, which is supported by The Royal Foundation and published by Penguin Random House companies,showcases over 50 recipes from women whose community was affected by the Grenfell Tower fire. In the book's foreword she writes: I immediately felt connected to this community kitchen it is a place for women to laugh, grieve, cry and cook together. Melding cultural identities under a shared roof, it creates a space to feel a sense of normalcy – in its simplest form, the universal need to connect, nurture, and commune through food, through crisis or joy – something we can all relate to…  Through this charitable endeavour, the proceeds will allow the kitchen to thrive and keep the global spirit of community alive. The duchess went to meet those affected at least twice at the beginning of the year, including a trip to the Al Manaar community mosque, which lies in the shadow of the charred shell of Grenfell Tower. She was without Prince Harry but was accompanied by a royal protection officer and one of the prince’s aides. The visits were compared to many made by her late mother-in-law Princess Diana, who often carried out charity work in secret. Speaking at the time, a leading Grenfell community member said: Meghan's visits mean so much to us. She has a special place in our hearts. A royal source added: Ms Markle has regularly been making private visits to organisations as she gets to know the charity sector.

story: NewsMuller Lights no longer Syn-free on Slimming World - and they're not the only food changingMembers have been expressing how upset they are at the news - here's why the yogurts now have a Syn valueShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience10:30, 17 SEP 2018Updated12:56, 17 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/muller-lights-no-longer-syn-13259645,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPanic spread among Slimming World users on social media this morning following claims Muller Lights will no longer be 'free' to eat - and the company has since confirmed the news. Worry set in after a screenshot of a Facebook post, which seemingly belongs to a Slimming World consultant, was shared on Twitter. The post in the group, titled 'Zoes Loughborough SW' reads: a 175g pot of Mullerlight  will be 1 syn. The popular yogurts, which come in a iety of flavours, have previously always been 'free' on the Slimming World plan. This meant dieters could eat them without having to worry about subtracting numbers from their daily allowance of up to 15 Syns.  Since the post was shared on social media, worried Slimming World members have been expressing their concern.       Have you been eating lots of Muller Lights and are now concerned about the changes? Contact nicola.oakley@mirror The post also revealed that instant mashed potato and tinned pasta shapes in tomato sauce  will be increasing in Syn value. The Slimming World plan works by allowing its users to eat from a whole list of foods which are classed as 'free'. They also have allowances for 'healthy extras' every day and encourage 'speed food' - fruits and vegetables - to get the right amount of nutrients in members' diets. Treats are still allowed in moderation. Foods have a 'Syn' value and people following the Slimming World plan can eat between 5 and 15 'Syns' per day and still expect to lose weight on a weekly basis. Anyone eating a 'free' Muller Light every day will now have to lose 1 Syn from their daily allowance.  A Slimming World spokesperson said: “Our nutrition team routinely review our Food Optimising eating plan to ensure it’s up to date, in line with the latest guidance, and to take into account feedback from our 5,000 Consultants and 900,000 Slimming World members. “As part of this process, we’ve been looking at how to give our vegan members more choice, and we’re delighted that a number of vegan foods, including canned jackfruit and plain and unsmoked seitan, can now be enjoyed freely by slimmers following our plan. “In addition, a number of products – fat-free flavoured yogurts, tinned pasta shapes in tomato sauce and instant mashed potato – that were previously Free on our plan, meaning they could be eaten without weighing, counting or measuring, will now have a small Syn value .

title: mum blew 250000 inheritance 14
story: NewsMum blew £250,000 inheritance in 14 months - and now lives on the streetsLorna Webb was once flush with cash before her £600-a-day drug habit took holdShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRaymond Brown09:34, 17 SEP 2018Updated14:20, 17 SEP 2018NewsLorna Webb has revealed how her £600-a-day drug habit cost her everything "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman has revealed how she blew a &pound250,000 inheritance, ended up sleeping rough and lost contact with her daughters because of her drug and alcohol addiction. Lorna Webb was married, had children and was once flush with cash, before her &pound600-a-day drug habit took hold. She has shared her heartbreaking story with the Cambridgeshire Live . Lorna clearly attempts to keep up a good appearance despite having slept outdoors in all weathers for many years. Now she struggles to eat but she once she owned two properties in Cambridge and worked in catering for many years in Wolfson College and other kitchens.  Several years ago - Lorna can't quite remember - she inherited &pound250,000 from her family. This was to be spent on drugs - and Lorna's innate generosity and kindness meant that she spent a lot of her inheritance on other struggling addicts.  She once was flush with cash and was spending almost &pound18,000 a month on drugs or &pound600 a day. Lorna now had the inheritance and started to spend. She said: When I got the money I was living locally, staying round friends and everything. My mates are all addicts so there was no way that I was going to leave them without. If I could have balanced it a bit more I would have done something with it. I am glad the money went to the area. The dollar has got invested. I don't mean any disrespect to my family. I lost a lot of weight and had a nervous breakdown. The heroin stopped me eating. It's very painful when you put weight back on your body and then you lose it. When you have a nervous breakdown it is very painful to your body. Lorna said she then attempted to rent a home in Cambridge but even with a small fortune in the bank she said no-one would let a property to her.  She said: I am an addict myself and I was dossing around dferent places. I tried to get a place but they weren't having none of it. That's what I don't understand. I had local connections and I was trying to rent a place. I had money to buy. I would have got a boat. Somebody must have been using my ID, plus the fact that I am adopted which doesn't help. Lorna spent most of her inheritance on feeding her habit and giving money away to addicts. She has little to show for it now and lives a hand-to-mouth existence. And in a heartbreaking moment, Lorna admitted her regret in not giving more of the money to her daughters and how she longs to see them again. The day before she spoke to Cambridgeshire Live she thought her daughter had driven past the spot in Mill Road where Lorna can be found on most days. She said: I guess I bought a few little bits and pieces - some jewellery. I bought both my girls some school kits. I love my girls. I have heard that they are doing really well. I hope so. I haven't seen them. I don't know  that was my daughter that I waved to the other day. I am not sure where they are. I would just like to see that they are safe. Sasha will be coming up to her mid-twenties and Faith eight years behind. They are both firing on all cylinders. They have all their pistons.  Lorna spoke of her le on the street and the camaraderie she felt with other rough sleepers. And she told of how many of her pals had been lost to drugs and violence. She said: It's not too bad on the street. We have a good crew around and we all look out for each other. Everyone has their own situation but no one will let anyone down. We've all got each others backs here. We've just lost some friends recently, but there's no way anyone is going to go unnoticed. No chance. That's not happening. Lorna also knew Peter Anderson, also known as Blue, who died from multiple stab wounds after being attacked on Stourbridge Common on July 25. Two London men have been charged with murder. Lorna said Blue was a gentle man and was shocked when she learned he had died. She added: I knew Blue. It is surreal to me like it hasn't happened. It's just surreal. I don't get it. And she spoke of the trouble in Mill Road and how traders wanted to clean up the area. She said: I score here but I've not noticed much trouble. It's probably other people getting involved and other people coming down here  the truth be known. I know people locally and there are things that they go through. But I think it's other people getting involved. Asked  she would have done things dferently, she said: I had wanted to bless my children. I wanted something for them. Lorna has been through the courts over the years. In March 2012 armed police were called in after Lorna was seen carrying a kne by an ambulance crew. She was jailed for eight months after Cambridge Crown Court heard she had armed herself for protection before a confrontation with another woman.

story: NewsMum claims £4.50 cream healed son's eczema in a WEEK after years of 'looking like burns victim'Mum Cory Lloyd says her son Jack's eczema become so severe she stopped taking him out due to hurtful comments from strangersShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'LearyErin Cardf09:09, 17 SEP 2018Updated12:41, 17 SEP 2018NewsCory with her sons Jack, three, and Alfie, one "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum claims a &pound4.50 cream healed her toddler son's eczema in just one week after years of him looking like a burns victim. Cory Lloyd's son Jack developed the skin condition at just three months old, before it become so severe she stopped taking him out due to hurtful comments from strangers. The little boy, now three, suffered such severe dry and cracked patches of skin he needed to wear a special moisturising suit under his clothes virtually around the clock. But his le changed, according to his mum, after Cory was tagged in a Facebook post about skincare brand Childs Farm, tried it and saw his skin clear within a week. Play centre worker Cory, 23, from, Darwen, Lancashire, said: “I was sceptical as we had tried so many things, but literally a week after trying it, his skin was clear.  When Jack’s eczema was really bad, I had to stop taking him out as much as I wanted, as instead of enjoying our mother and baby bonding time, I’d be so conscious about people staring at him. “Once a lady said to her friend, ‘Look at that little boy, he’s had a terrible fall, his mum must not have been looking after him.’ I just went home and cried. “All people saw was a young mum and they judged me, but they weren’t there for the sleepless nights and countless hospital appointments. I was doing everything I could and getting nowhere.” Cory, who has another son, Alfie, one, with her joiner partner Ben Holmes, 23, said Jack seemed perfectly healthy until he reached three months, when crusty patches began to spring up on his forehead. Has your child faced a similar issue? Email webnews@trinitymirror  Thinking it was just standard dry skin, she applied special baby moisturiser – but it made little dference. Then, when the patches also began to weep, Cory consulted a doctor, who diagnosed eczema. “Within a couple of months, the eczema had spread all over Jack’s body,” she recalled. “I’d be coating him in moisturiser five times a day and tried so many dferent creams, steroids and antibiotics that the doctor prescribed, but nothing seemed to help. “He’d wake up every morning with blood on his sheets from where his skin had cracked in the night. “Eventually, I reached my wits end, went to the doctor and said, ‘I’m not leaving until I have a referral to a specialist.’”  Thankfully, when he was around 18 months old, Jack was referred to a dermatologist, who prescribed a special suit designed to keep moisture in and stop his clothes from absorbing the creams Cory was applying. Required to wear it every day under his clothes, it meant he did not want to play with the other children at nursery, as he knew running about would irritate his skin. In addition to the suit, Cory bandaged Jack’s legs and arms, in a bid to keep the moisture in. “I could bandage his limbs, but his torso was the worst place for eczema, she said. “It felt like sandpaper. He literally looked like a burns victim.” Desperate, Cory even asked doctors for an allergy test to see  something in Jack’s diet was triggering the agonising outbreaks – but a cause has never been found.

title: my six pack saved life
story: News'My six-pack saved my le': Gym addict's miracle escape after being run over by a two-ton truckEXCLUSIVE: Muscly Jack Moore, 21, was dozing in a park with girlfriend Vicky Clarke when the tyres of the two-ton vehicle rolled across themShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLiz Dunphy12:29, 17 SEP 2018Updated12:30, 17 SEP 2018NewsJack Moore narrowly escaped death when a dump truck drove over him while he was sunbathing in a park "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA gym addict who was run over by a truck has told how doctors believe his hard six-pack saved his le. Muscly Jack Moore, 21, was dozing in a park with girlfriend Vicky Clarke when the tyres of the two-ton vehicle rolled across them. Jack suffered horrendous internal injuries including broken ribs, a collapsed lung and liver damage. But medics said the keep-fit fan – who turned to exercise and diet at 17 after hitting an obese 16st – could have been killed had it not been for his ripped washboard stomach. Jack, whose six-pack was cut away to be replaced with an 8in scar and tyre tread mark, said: The doctors said I was lucky I had more muscle otherwise I would probably have suffered more injuries. “They said I was very healthy and that was also a big factor in my recovery.”  Jack and Vicky, 19, had just cuddled down on the grass beside a river in Earlham Park, Norwich, and shut their eyes when horror struck in June 2017. The Toyota Hilux, which was going round emptying litter bins, went over both of them as onlookers screamed. Jack recalled: I opened my eyes and the truck was about a foot away from my head. I had no time to react and I just had to watch it happen. The front wheel crunched over my stomach which was really mentally distressing. It was the last thing I expected to happen and I think adrenaline kicked in so I did not feel the pain immediately. Then it drove over Vicky, stopped on her and started to reverse. I pulled myself back out from underneath it before it could run over me again. Then my stomach felt extremely painful and I knew something was seriously wrong with my body.  I pulled up my t-shirt to look at it and it was really deformed and disfugured. My belly button was not in the centre anymore, it had been pushed off to the left. The thread details of the tyre were etched into my skin and the right side of my stomach was very red. Then the pain really kicked in. I tried to scream but my lung was punctured so I couldn't really do it. A little girl was the first person who rushed over to me, bless her heart, followed by her dad. Then about 10 people were around me, telling me to breathe and stay conscious. They were asking me what my name was and what day it was. It was dficult to speak and I just wanted to curl up in a ball alone with the pain but the people around me would not let me move. I'm lucky they were there because I probably would have lost even more blood internally  I had moved. Someone had called an ambulance and although it felt like an eternity waiting on the grass, it was actually really quick, we were lucky that the hospital was just one quarter of a mile away.  The truck had punctured my lung, tore my kidney in two places, tore my liver, broke two ribs and I lost one litre of blood through internal bleeding. I lost so much blood that I started slipping in and out of consiousness. I remember the police arriving and a police woman standing over me, blocking the sun from my eyes. And I vaguely remember the ambulance arriving and the paramedics giving me an epidural and gas in the park before I passed out. Jack was rushed to hospital for emergency le-saving treatment. Jack said: My next clear memory is waking up in a hospital bed. My stomach was extremely painful. I pulled back the covers and saw a huge scar running from under my nipple to my groin.  I had tubes all over me with about six cannulas in just one hand. I had a big needle in my spine for the epidural and I had another tube coming out of my arm. I panicked. I did not know what happened. Was my partner ok? My mum was by my bed and she told me Vicky had been hit but she was alive. I think I was pretty out of it with all the painkillers but then it all started flooding back to me like a dream after you've just woken up. Jack, who is being represented by personal injury specialist Slater and Gordon in a civil case, recovered after a hospital stay but was left with problems including not being able to use the loo properly.  He was also diagnosed with PTSD.  He said: I still have abdominal pain and I was diagnosed with PTSD. Recovering psychologically has been more dficult than the physical aspects. I still get flashbacks of the moment I saw the wheel on my right side and watched as it drove over me. It was really traumatic. The park was a place where I always felt safe before. I've gone there for years walking my dog and there are always families and children there. It’s really knocked my confidence but I'm determined to get better again. I feel lucky to be alive and I hope that I can heal.” Vicky suffered broken vertebrae, a broken collarbone and a fractured sternum in the horror crush. She was admitted to hospital for treatment alongside Jack but she has since also been released.

story: News'Nice big t*** babe': Breastfeeding blogger inundated with messages from creepy men and adult baby fetish loversAmi Roberts - who has two sons, 'Pickle' and 'Smidge' - originally set up her blog Through Ami's Eyes as a way to empower women and fight the taboo around breastfeeding in publicShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByHana Carter14:00, 17 SEP 2018NewsAmi Roberts, 29, has her own breastfeeding blog to empower other women "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA breastfeeding blogger has slammed the men who send her 'sleazy messages' when she posts photos of her nursing her son. Ami Roberts, 29, originally set up her blog Through Ami's Eyes as a way to empower other women and fight the taboo around breastfeeding in public. But after creating her website, she began to receive sexual comments on social media 'praising' her breasts and even had inappropriate messages from adult baby lover fetish groups. Ami, who doesn't give away the identity of her children, said: “What I don’t understand is,  there is a newspaper or magazine with page three content on it, people don't bat an eyelid. “As a society we’re used to seeing boobs used for advertisements but when they’re seen being used for the most natural reason some people don’t like it. “They get uncomfortable and feel they have a right to comment. “Then at the other end of the scale there are men who comment on my social media channels saying ‘I love your boobs’.  “I’ve written back to these men, many of whom have partners and children, asking them how they expect me to reply, should I say, ‘thanks, I’m so glad you like my boobs’? “What do they expect to achieve from this apart from making women feeling embarrassed and that they shouldn’t be feeding in public? “I’ve even had a man send a picture of himself wearing an adult diaper. I replied to him that that wasn’t the purpose of the post and then I blocked him. “I’m headstrong and very confident about feeding in public but  another mum who wasn't as confident posted pictures and received messages like that it could really put them off and that’s not fair.” She decided to blog about her breastfeeding experiences after she was shamed for feeding her son 'Smidge'. Ami said: “I was feeding Smidge behind a partition in the caf&eacute area of the gym while my other son was at a swimming lesson three months ago. “There was another group of people sat five tables away and a guy in his fties looked over, tutted and said ‘they shouldn’t be allowed to do that in here where people are eating’ and moved away. “That was my first ever negative comment and I didn’t know how to deal with it. Now I look back and wish I’d said ‘I’m not squirting it on your toast, how can you feel that you can comment on this?’ “Three months down the line this experience has spurred me on not to cover up, especially with the hot summer we’ve just had. “Putting a cover over him as he fed would have made us both hot and sweaty.  “I want women to know their rights. It’s a woman’s right to feed her baby, we’re not doing anything wrong. “If you saw a man walking down the street with no shirt on and his nipples out no matter what that man looks like nobody says anything. “Why should we as women doing something completely natural have to hide away? We shouldn’t. It’s not wrong, there’s no reason to feel any shame. “I want to help women and that’s why I’ve shared breastfeeding pictures on my social media channels to show women there’s nothing to hide. “I’ve since received comments from blog readers saying that after seeing my photos it gave them the confidence to feed in public which is great.” But sharing this empowering breastfeeding advocate message on social media has attracted unwanted attention from men who sexualise the images.  Ami said: “Since sharing these pictures there’s been a big influx of men to my Instagram account sending messages every other day who feel it’s ok to comment on my breasts. “I think sometimes it’s to try and embarrass me but 80 percent of the time it’s sexual. I don't know what they are trying to achieve other than make me sick. “I’m not putting these pictures on Instagram to display myself. I’m not wearing sexy lingerie, I’m wearing a nursing bra and I’m doing it to raise awareness of breastfeeding in public, something I’m really passionate about. Typical comments Ami receives include: ‘Nice big tits babe, keep up the content’ and ‘I want to get to know you better’. One of the more bizarre messages was from a self-professed ABDL who wrote: “I grew up home schooled my entire le in a very nurturing household. “I joined the army at 18, it was an eye opener. Now that I’m older I’ve reverted to being a little ABDL for comfort not in a sexual way, pls pls [sic] don’t take it this way. I’m just seeking somebody mature that might understand.” Ami said: “When I've replied to people their responses have been mixed. One said ‘well I really like them and I can’t help that’ and thought that was acceptable. “Another apologised and said he didn’t think I’d read it – my argument is why send it in the first place?  “Some make excuses and say ‘sorry I didn’t mean to offend you’ whereas the adult diaper guy was told that it wasn’t what the post was about and I blocked him. “Nine out of ten of the people behind these comments wouldn’t say anything to your face but think it’s acceptable when they do it from behind a computer screen, it’s disgusting.” Ami’s husband business manager John Roberts, 29, said he was repulsed by the vile comments she was subjected to. John said: “It’s disgusting, it just shows what people expect to get away with. “They don't seem educated enough to respect women like my we who are trying to do the best by their kids.” Ami, who is a Lansinoh ambassador, said she wants to support all mums – who either choose to bottle or breastfeed their children.

title: nine year old boy humiliated
story: NewsSchoolboy, nine, 'humiliated' in front of classmates after 'being told to get hair cut during assembly'Security worker Noor Nawab, 31, claims his young boy Adam was left mortied by the requestShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMike Lockly10:26, 17 SEP 2018Updated12:41, 17 SEP 2018NewsAdam Noor, nine, was allegedly singled out during assembly "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An outraged dad claims his young son was 'humiliated' after being told to get his hair cut during assembly on the first day back at school .  Noor Nawab, from Saltley, Birmingham, claims nine-year-old Adam was left embarrassed after being singled out in front of his classmates.  The 31-year-old security worker says Adderly Primary School gave Adam the edict in front of the entire school, Birmingham Live reports.  And, he alleges, staff even made him stand up. “If there was a problem with my son’s hair, why not tell me about it or send a letter home?” said Noor.  “If they told me, I’d just ask ‘Why?’ He added: “Yes, I’m angry, but getting angry at staff gets you nowhere. He is shy and upset about it. They made him stand up in front of classmates and humiliated him.” The school says it has a clear policy on school unorm on its website. Adam has not had a haircut for years, his dad admits, and it is now beyond shoulder . “At the front, his hair is past his nose, at the back it’s beyond his shoulders,” said Noor. “It’s a fashion thing and I can’t see a problem. He has nice, long, thick hair.” He has vowed that Adam will not be visiting the barbers.  On its website, Adderley Primary describes itself as “rights respecting”. The school unorm policy states: “Whilst we respect the backgrounds, cultures and beliefs of all our families, we expect all pupils to maintain an appropriate and sensible haircut which is at the discretion of the Headteacher and School Leadership Team. “Pupils are not permitted to have any kind of patterns or lines cut into their hair. This includes ‘v’ cuts or ‘Mohican’-type styles. This also extends to patterns on eyebrows. Neither are they allowed to have articially coloured hair. It continued: “Pupils will be continually made aware of this through assemblies and ongoing school unorm monitoring by all staff. Parents will be reminded of this through newsletters and conversations with staff.

story: NewsWhat it is like to be on monkey dust - former athlete describes taking drug that's 10 times stronger than cocaineAn expectant father has revealed the disturbing effects of the drug monkey dust - and has pledged never to take it againShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAimi Redfern09:36, 17 SEP 2018Updated10:13, 17 SEP 2018NewsRio Bailey says he has been off the drug for two weeks "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn expectant dad says monkey dust took over his le - and claims the drug is TEN times stronger than cocaine.  Rio Bailey, 25, says the disturbing effects of the drug made him hear voices in his head and turned him into a paranoid wreck, the Stoke Sentinel reported .  The once-promising athlete was introduced to the drug last year but has vowed to never take it again as he prepares for the birth of his first child. Rio, who lives in Madeley, Stoke on Trent, said: “Since I was 18 I’ve taken MDMA and cocaine, but it’s only in the last year I’ve started experimenting with monkey dust.  “I knew someone who dealt in drugs. I got told it was like cocaine but it lasts 10 times longer. I was using it for escapism and that’s the go-to drug because it lasts so long. I would say it is 10 times stronger than coke. “There’s a euphoria to it. I’m fully aware of what I was doing when I’ve taken it, but you’ve got so much energy you just want to keep moving.  “It’s highly mentally addictive. You can start hearing voices with it. “It’s like any drug though - how it affects you depends on the person taking it.”  Staffordshire Police has revealed officers have dealt with 950 incidents associated with the drug in just three months. Meanwhile paramedics say they are regularly called to deal with users who have taken the substance, which can be bought on the streets of Stoke-on-Trent for as little as &pound2. Rio said he was surprised by the number of people that were taking it, and believes it is so popular because it's so cheap. He said: “You smoke it, and it costs a couple of quid for a hit. “I would go two months without taking it, then go on a bender for a week. I’ve got anger issues and when that got triggered I would take it. “Dealers will give people their first hit for free, just so they can get people hooked. It’s so cheap.” Rio was a keen athlete before going to Manchester politan University to study sports management. He found it too expensive to continue to compete, but graduated with a degree and moved back to the area when he was 22. Monkey Dust, also known as MDPV, causes hallucinations and paranoia. People on the drug, which looks like an off-white powder, have been known to climb trees and buildings and attack people who come near them. It's from a family of drugs known as cathinones as can be bought for as little as &pound2. Monkey dust can be swallowed, injected or snorted and it dampens perceptions of pain. It can also cause powerful hallucinations which lead to severe paranoia. The use of monkey dust is on the rise because of its low cost and its effects can be felt after ingesting small amounts - as little as 3mg. While Staffordshire is a known epicentre for the drug, West Midlands Ambulance Service said it has dealt with cases across the region. Paramedics have been called to 178 incidents since April involving money dust — 131 of them in North Staffordshire.    Now, he is due to become a dad in three months, and says that has been the catalyst that's made him want to change his ways. He said: “I’m not going to take it again. It would be selfish  I did, with a kid on the way. “If I was giving advice to someone thinking of taking it, I would say don’t. It’s not going to resolve any issues you have, when you come down from it your issues are going to be ten times worse.” Rio’s dad, Baz Bailey, said seeing the effect monkey dust had on his son was ‘heartbreaking’. The 48-year-old dad-of-four said: “At one stage he would be okay, then just go missing for a fortnight.

title: inside colourful quirky defqon1 dance
story: NewsDefqon.1 dance festival: Inside Sydney event which left two dead and 700 needing medical treatmentFancy dress outfits, sequins, body paint, wigs and masks were among the items donned by revellers at the event in SydneyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLidia KellyDanya BazaraaNews Reporter20:32, 16 SEP 2018Updated23:19, 16 SEP 2018NewsRevellers enjoying themselves at Defcon.1 dance festival in Sydney where two people died and 700 needed medical treatment "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Revellers danced in colourful and quirky clothing at a music festival which left two people dead and 700 needing medical assistance.  Flower headdresses and suspenders were among the items party-goers donned at the Defqon.1 festival in Sydney, Australia. Some decorated their bodies and faces with paint, while others went for masks, wigs and fancy dress costumes. Many women were pictured in bikinis and men in swim shorts. People were photographed enjoying themselves with groups of friends, but the event ended in tragedy.   Two people died, a dozen more were taken to hospital and hundreds others sought medical assistance after suspected drug overdoses at a music festival in Sydney, the police said.  A 23-year-old man and a 21-year-old woman died on Saturday after collapsing at the Defqon.1 festival, the police said. Two of the 13 hospitalised people remain in critical condition, while about 700 sought assistance on site.  The police has charged 10 people with drug supply offences, including two teenagers who allegedly carried 120 capsules to the festival, held at the Sydney International Regatta Centre.   I'm absolutely aghast at what has occurred, I don't want any family to go through the tragedy that some families are waking up to this morning, it's just horrible to think about, the premier of the Australian state of New South Wales, Gladys Berejiklian , said.   This is an unsafe event and I'll be doing everything I can to make sure it never happens again, she added. Ms Berejuklian denied cancelling the event would force it and others to go underground, and said pill-testing at music events was not a solution. Anyone who advocates pill-testing is giving the green light to drugs. There is no such thing as a safe drug and unfortunately when young people think there is, it has tragic consequences, she said. In 2013 and 2015, two men in their 20s died while attending the festival, both of suspected drug overdose.  The festival, an annual event held in Australia since 2009, has been organised by Q-Dance Australia, part of the Dutch event organiser Q-Dance. On Sunday, the organisers said they were deeply saddened by the deaths. We are disappointed at the number of reported drug-related incidents, we have a zero-tolerance policy in relation to drug use at the festival, Defqon.1 said in a statement published by the Sydney Morning Herald. In total, 69 people were found in possession of drugs at the festival held at Sydney International Regatta Centre.  Local detectives have formed a new police strikeforce, dubbed Highworth, to investigate the two deaths. About 30,000 revellers attended this year's event. New South Wales Police Acting Assistant Commissioner, Allan Sicard, said police had done everything they could to ensure the event was safe.  What we can't do is be in people's heads, be in people's decision-making processes when they decide to take illicit drugs, he said, according to ABC.  Police can only do so much.

story: NewsMalaysia Airlines Flight MH17: Russia claims it was really Ukraine who shot down jet over war zoneThe Buk missile was built near Moscow and delivered to a Ukrainian military unit in 1986, Russia's defence ministry claimsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitching10:44, 17 SEP 2018Updated11:07, 17 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/world-news/video/malaysian-airlines-flight-mh17-downed-8932316,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRussia has sensationally claimed Ukraine shot down Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, saying it didn't have the missile that brought down the doomed jet. The Buk missile was built at a plant near Moscow during the Cold War and delivered to Ukraine in 1986 when it was a Soviet republic, the Kremlin claims. A team of international investigators has pointed the blame at Moscow, saying videos and other evidence show a missile launcher being secretly transported into territory held by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine. The investigators claim a Russian-made Buk missile brought down the jet and the launcher used in the air disaster - which killed all 298 passengers and crew onboard - belonged to Russia's military.  But Russia's Ministry of Defence claims those videos have been manipulated, and denies claims that Moscow was involved in the July 2014 tragedy of the flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur. At a news conference on Monday, Russia's military provided an audio recording which it claims is proof that Ukraine was involved in the air disaster. It claims that the missile used to bring down the jet was no longer in its hands.  Russian officials claim serial numbers found on missile fragments show the weapon was built in 1986 and it was owned by Ukraine when the jet was shot down. General Nikolay Parshin told reporters that the missile was sent to Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic military unit 20152, which is now the 223rd anti-aircraft defence regiment of Ukraine's armed forces. The general claims that unit was involved in Ukraine's offensive against Russian-backed separatists in the Donetsk region in June 2014, just weeks before the airliner was shot down.  In May, the international team of investigators, led by the Netherlands, said Russia's armed forces supplied the missile launcher that fired a Russian-made Buk missile at MH17 over the war zone. Wilbert Paulissen, head of the Netherlands' national police crime squad, said the missile was fired from Russia's 53rd Anti-Aircraft Brigade. Moscow is not involved in that investigation, and claims the probe is biased.

title: dundee families in shock after popular support scheme closes due to lack of funds
story: Families have been left shocked after a popular support scheme announced it was closing due to a lack of funds.The Child and Family Project based in Chalmers Ardler Church revealed it would close next month as it could no longer fund a project leader.The group has been in operation for 27 years and used a range of grants to support the leader’s £24,000 a year salary, but will now close on October 5 as it no longer has the moneys to continue.Dad-of-four Tarig Brady, 33, whose twin daughters attended one of the group’s services, said he had no idea it was struggling with funding.He said: “It is a major shock and it is definitely going to be a big loss to the community. I hope something can be done.”After retiring from the scheme in 2016, former project leader Christine Black said: “Funding has always been a problem and it is a really sad situation.“It is an enormous loss because the group gives people friendships, a leline and parenting skills.”Trustee Renee Fordes said: “We have had to close because the project leader has handed in her notice and there are no funds to provide another salary. title: dundee united new boy booth says he shouldnt have tried to run off injury
story: Callum Booth admits had he been a Dundee United veteran instead of a rookie, two months into the season Arabs would have seen a lot more of him than they have.The 27-year-old is ready for today’s Championship clash with Morton at Tannadice and,  he completes the 90 minutes, it will be the first time since his debut in mid-July.That’s when he damaged ankle ligaments in the Betfred Cup defeat at Ross County, an injury suffered early on in the tie.It could have forced him off immediately but the fact he played on was, he admits, a mistake on his part that was caused by him being new to the team.“Firstly, it’s been good to be back, obviously being out for five weeks was a long time,” said the former Partick Thistle defender.“It felt like ages, especially when you join a new club because you just want to make good impressions and get games under your belt right away.“It was my ankle, I did in it in the first half at Ross County and quite stupidly played on.“The physio came on, had a look and I thought I could probably run it off. I did feel it for the rest of the game but being at a new club you just want to show up well in your first game.“If I’d been here a couple of years I would have come off but, because it was my first game, I stayed on and probably made it worse – I woke up the next day and it was agony.“The result was five weeks out and that wasn’t ideal but it’s in the past now and I’m raring to go.”What he isn’t doing is expecting to walk right back into the team and he knows, in the shape of fellow left-back Jamie Robson, he’s facing strong competition for that defensive berth.“Jamie has been doing really well, he’s a good player and it’s good to have competition. There are a few boys still out and they’re coming back, so there’s going to be even more and that can only be good for the squad.“I feel that, when we have everyone fit, we have a very strong squad and it’s just going to be a case of getting everyone fit and keeping it that way. There are always injuries, though, it’s part and parcel of football.”His mission now is to help however he can as United look to keep picking up points to mount a strong promotion challenge.The aim today is to pick up three points. He knows that will not be easy against a Morton side who will be something of an unknown quantity after their recent change of manager.It saw ex-United boss Ray McKinnon quit after just three months in chare to take over at Falkirk and former Rangers star Jonatan Johansson replace him.“Any team that gets a new manager, they usually take a couple of weeks to implement what the new man is trying to do. This is Johansson’s first game in charge so we are not really too sure how they’ll set up.“One thing we know is they have good inidual players and experience in there as well in the middle of the park.“It’s going to be a tough game and they are a good side. They’ve had a good couple of seasons where they’ve always been in or close to the play-offs and done well in a few cups.”For United the aim is to build on a three-game unbeaten run that’s seen seven points taken from the last nine, though Booth believes it should have been a full house.“We are going not too bad but,  we want to be winning the league, we have to be holding on to results like the one we should have had at Alloa last time out.“We didn’t play great but 1-0 going into the last 10 minutes, we should have seen the game out.
